AVSEC ORDER NO. 1/2004

Sub: X-ray Screening of International Export Cargo

In continuation of AVSEC Order No. 1/2002 dated 14.2.2002 on the subject cited
above, Commissioner of Security (Civil Aviation), Bureau of Civil Aviation in the
exercise of powers conferred by Section SA of Aircraft Act 1934 delegated to him vide
Government of India, Ministry of Civil Aviation Notification No. 1797 dated July 3,
1997 for the purpose of securing the safety of aircraft operations directs that:

(i) In case of cargo consignments which can neither be x-rayed nor can be
physically checked on account of the nature of the consignments, the airline
operators shall certify in each case that a particular consignment intended for
export can neither be x-rayed nor physically checked. In such case the airline
operators may transport such consignments only after observing 24 hours
cooling off period.

(ii) A proper record shall be maintained by the airline operators of the security
procedure implemented by them and will be made available for inspection by

the BCAS officers.

AYSEC ORDER NO. 1/2002
Sub:® X-ray screening of Intemational Export Carmo.

? As per the Standards of Annex 17 to the Convention on Intemational Aviation it is
mandatory to establish measures to ensure that the cargo consignments intended to be carried by ait
are subjected to appropriate security controls.

In view of the above and also the threat perception from terrorists outfits to civil aviation
operations Commissioner of Security(Civil Aviation), Bureau of Civil Aviation Security , in
exercise of powers conferred by Section SA of Aircraft Act 1934 delegated to him vide
Government of India, Ministry of Civil Aviation Notification No. 1797 dated July 3, 1997 for the
purpose of securing the safety of aircraft operation directs that the following instructions, with
regard to security check of intemational export cargo shall be implemented before loading the cargo
into the aircraft for transportation:~

i) ‘That all international export cargo consignment shall be subjected to x-ray screening by
the trained security staff of concemed airlines , who are certified by BCAS

ii) ‘That the international cargo consignments which cannot be screened through x-ray due
to size constraints, volume or contents of the consignments , the same shall be
physically checked by the security staff mentioned above and security sticker
indicating the procedure of security check applied shall be affixed on each
consignment.

iii) ‘That 24 hours “cooling off” of the cargo consignments intended for international
export shall not be accepted as an alternate security system.

tv) ‘That APSU shall ensure that the above measures have been taken by the airlines
operator and in token of confirmation , the cargo manifest shall be countersigned by the
responsible officer of APSU on duty before transportation to airside for loading.

v) That legal action Under Section 11 A of Aircraft Act 1934 shall be taken against the
Air Operators who violate the above directions. Such export cargo-consignment. shall
not be allowed for loading in to the aircraft by APSU on duty.

vi) That above directions will take effect from 1" June 2002. Airport Management/ Airline
Operator shall ensure procurement and installation of x-ray machines for the above

purpose by the due date as netified above.
